[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: get_sources()] [Filename Injection] The find_move_filenames() call uses user-controlled paths - can an attacker provide paths with special characters that cause the file finder to return unauthorized files? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: get_sources()] [Symbol Pool Exhaustion] Converting filenames to Symbol allocates in symbol pool - can an attacker provide millions of source files to exhaust the symbol pool memory? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: get_bytecodes()] [Extension Check Bypass] The extension_equals() check for MOVE_COMPILED_EXTENSION - can an attacker provide files with double extensions or case variations that bypass this check and include malicious bytecode? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: transitive_dependencies()] [Infinite Recursion] The function recursively calls itself via resolve_package closure - can an attacker craft a dependency structure that causes stack overflow despite cycle detection in graph building? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: transitive_dependencies()] [Unwrap Panic] The code uses unwrap() when getting packages from package_table - can an attacker exploit race conditions where packages are removed during traversal, causing panic? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: transitive_dependencies()] [Order Dependency] The function uses BTreeSet for 'seen' tracking - can an attacker exploit ordering differences across platforms to cause inconsistent dependency resolution? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: transitive_dependencies()] [Memory Exhaustion] For packages with many transitive dependencies, can an attacker cause O(N^2) memory usage by crafting diamond-shaped dependency graphs where many paths lead to same packages? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: transitive_dependencies()] [Collect Timing] The needless_collect clippy warning is suppressed - is there a timing vulnerability in collecting to Vec before filtering that could be exploited? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: immediate_dependencies()] [Dev Mode Leak] When build_options.dev_mode is true, dev_dependencies are included - can an attacker exploit this to leak information about dev-only dependencies in production by checking which dependencies are resolved? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: file_sources()] [Unwrap Panic] Multiple unwrap() calls on fs::read_to_string() - can an attacker create files that exist during get_sources() but are deleted before read_to_string(), causing panic? [File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: file_sources()] [Hash Collision] FileHash is computed from file contents - can an attacker find hash collisions to make different source files appear identical, bypassing duplicate checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/third_party/move/tools/move-package/src/resolution/resolution_graph.rs] [Function: file_sources()] [Memory Exhaustion] Reading all source files into memory - can an attacker provide extremely large source files that cause OOM when loaded? (High)
